Definition: Fundamental condition where limited resources cannot satisfy unlimited human wants, forcing choices about resource allocation
Example: Even in a wealthy country, time and skilled labor are limited so not all projects can be completed
CLEP Trap: Often confused with a temporary shortage; scarcity is permanent and universal, shortages are temporary market conditions

Definition: Value of the next best alternative forgone when a choice is made
Example: Choosing to study for an exam instead of working a paid shift; opportunity cost is the wages you didn't earn
CLEP Trap: Students list all alternatives as cost; only the single highest-valued foregone option counts

Definition: The idea that getting more of one good requires giving up some of another due to scarcity
Example: Government spending more on defense may require less spending on education or healthcare
CLEP Trap: Students equate 'trade-off' with only money cost and ignore time or resource costs

Definition: Graph that shows maximum combinations of two goods an economy can produce with given resources and technology
Example: PPC between consumer goods and capital goods showing frontier of possible combinations
CLEP Trap: Points inside the PPC are attainable but inefficient; outside points are unattainable with current resources

Definition: Increase in the economy's capacity to produce, represented by an outward shift of the entire PPC
Example: Improved technology in both agriculture and manufacturing shifts PPC outward
CLEP Trap: Students think moving along an existing PPC is growth; that is just reallocating resources, not increasing capacity

Definition: Ability to produce more of a good with the same amount of resources than another producer
Example: Country A can produce 10 tons of steel while Country B can produce 6 tons with same inputs; A has absolute advantage
CLEP Trap: Used incorrectly as the basis for trade decisions; CLEP focuses on comparative advantage for specialization

Definition: Ability to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another producer, guiding specialization and trade
Example: If Country A gives up 2 units of cloth for 1 unit of wheat while Country B gives up 4 units, A has comparative advantage in wheat
CLEP Trap: Students pick the country that produces the most (absolute advantage) instead of the one with lower opportunity cost

Definition: Agreed exchange rate between goods that allows both countries to benefit from trade
Example: If A trades 1 wheat for between 2 and 4 cloth with B, both gain from trade
CLEP Trap: Students choose trade ratios outside the range between the two opportunity costs, which would hurt one trading partner
Related Formula/Relationship: Must lie between each country's opportunity cost for the traded good

Definition: Ceteris paribus, as price falls, quantity demanded rises; as price rises, quantity demanded falls
Example: A drop in movie ticket prices leads to more tickets purchased, holding other factors constant
CLEP Trap: Confusing 'change in demand' (shift) with 'change in quantity demanded' (movement along curve)
Related Formula/Relationship: Inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded

Definition: Ceteris paribus, as price rises, quantity supplied rises; as price falls, quantity supplied falls
Example: Higher corn prices induce farmers to plant more corn
CLEP Trap: Students call movement along supply curve an 'increase in supply' when only price changed
Related Formula/Relationship: Direct relationship between price and quantity supplied

Definition: Price and quantity at which quantity demanded equals quantity supplied
Example: At $5 per unit, buyers want 100 units and sellers supply 100 units
CLEP Trap: Students think equilibrium is 'fair' or 'socially optimal'; it's just where Qd = Qs

Definition: Quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied at a price below equilibrium
Example: Price of $3 when equilibrium is $5 leads to more buyers than sellers
CLEP Trap: Often mislabeled as surplus because price is 'low'; must compare Qd and Qs

Definition: Quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded at a price above equilibrium
Example: Price of $7 when equilibrium is $5 leaves unsold inventory
CLEP Trap: Students reverse shortage and surplus definitions if they focus only on price level

Definition: Legal maximum price; if set below equilibrium it is binding and creates a shortage
Example: Rent control that caps rent below market rate
CLEP Trap: Students confuse which control causes shortage; it's the binding ceiling, not floor

Definition: Legal minimum price; if set above equilibrium it is binding and creates a surplus
Example: Minimum wage set above equilibrium wage causing excess labor supplied
CLEP Trap: Students often claim floors cause shortages; binding floors cause surpluses

Definition: Non-price factors that shift demand: income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, number of buyers
Example: An increase in consumer income shifts demand for new cars to the right
CLEP Trap: Students treat a change in the good's own price as a demand shifter instead of a movement along the curve

Definition: Non-price factors that shift supply: input costs, technology, taxes/subsidies, expectations, number of sellers
Example: A rise in oil prices raises production costs and shifts supply of plastic goods left
CLEP Trap: Students confuse shifts with movements caused solely by price changes

Definition: Tariffs are taxes on imports; quotas are limits on quantity of imports; both reduce imports and raise domestic prices
Example: A tariff on imported steel raises its price, boosting domestic producers but raising costs for steel users
CLEP Trap: Students forget that tariffs and quotas typically create deadweight loss and can provoke retaliation

Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Definition: Market value of all final goods and services produced within a country's borders in a given time period
Example: Cars, software, and haircuts produced in the US this year are included in US GDP
CLEP Trap: Students include intermediate goods or transfer payments like Social Security as part of GDP when they should be excluded

Definition: Method of calculating GDP by summing spending on final goods and services by households, firms, government, and net exports
Example: Adding up consumer spending, business investment, government purchases, and net exports
CLEP Trap: Confusing investment with stock purchases; in GDP, investment is business capital, new housing, inventories

Definition: Spending on capital goods, new residential construction, and changes in inventories
Example: A firm buys new machines and a developer builds a new apartment building
CLEP Trap: Students confuse financial investment (stocks, bonds) with real investment counted in GDP
Related Formula/Relationship: Part of I in GDP formula

Definition: Value of all final goods and services produced measured at current-year prices
Example: If prices double and output stays the same, nominal GDP doubles
CLEP Trap: Students think rising nominal GDP always means more output, ignoring inflation

Definition: Value of all final goods and services produced measured in base-year prices, adjusting for inflation
Example: Using 2015 prices to value output in 2024 to compare real output over time
CLEP Trap: Students confuse real GDP with GDP per capita or think it's unadjusted

Definition: Price index measuring average price of all goods and services in GDP
Example: If nominal GDP is 1100 and real GDP is 1000, deflator = 110
CLEP Trap: Students mix up CPI and GDP deflator or apply CPI basket formulas to GDP deflator questions

Definition: Index number showing how the average price of a basket changes over time relative to a base year
Example: CPI of 125 means prices are 25 percent higher than in base year on average
CLEP Trap: Forgetting to divide by base-year cost before multiplying by 100
Related Formula/Relationship: Price index = (current basket cost / base-year basket cost) * 100

Definition: Percentage change in the price index between two periods
Example: If CPI rises from 100 to 110, inflation is 10 percent
CLEP Trap: Students subtract indices but forget to divide by the earlier index, treating difference as percent

Definition: Price index that measures the cost of a fixed market basket of consumer goods and services over time
Example: CPI tracks average cost of typical urban consumer's basket of goods
CLEP Trap: Students apply CPI to all price-level questions, ignoring that GDP deflator covers all domestic production
Related Formula/Relationship: CPI = (current basket cost / base-year basket cost) * 100

Definition: Total number of people employed plus unemployed who are actively seeking work
Example: A retired person is not in the labor force; a job seeker sending applications is
CLEP Trap: Students include discouraged workers who have stopped looking in the labor force

Definition: Percentage of labor force that is unemployed and actively seeking work
Example: If 5 million unemployed out of 50 million labor force, unemployment rate is 10 percent
CLEP Trap: Students use total population instead of labor force in denominator

Definition: Short-term unemployment as workers move between jobs or enter/reenter the labor force
Example: A new college graduate searching for their first job
CLEP Trap: Students label all unemployment in good times as structural instead of frictional

Definition: Unemployment due to mismatch between workers' skills and job requirements
Example: Factory workers displaced by automation lacking skills for new tech jobs
CLEP Trap: Confused with cyclical unemployment during recessions

Definition: Unemployment caused by downturns in the business cycle, when aggregate demand is low
Example: Workers laid off during a recession because firms cut production
CLEP Trap: Students think any unemployment is structural; cyclical falls during expansions

Definition: Unemployment rate when economy is at full employment, including frictional and structural but not cyclical unemployment
Example: In many economies, often around 4–6 percent depending on structure
CLEP Trap: Students believe natural rate is zero; frictional and structural unemployment always exist

Definition: Short-run fluctuations in real GDP around the long-run trend: expansion, peak, recession, trough
Example: A multi-year pattern where GDP grows, peaks, then contracts in a recession
CLEP Trap: Students confuse business cycle (short-run) with long-run growth trend

Definition: Inflation caused by increases in aggregate demand that push prices up
Example: Government stimulus increases AD causing both higher price level and output in short run
CLEP Trap: Often confused with cost-push inflation; must identify which curve shifts (AD vs SRAS)

Definition: Inflation caused by decreases in short-run aggregate supply due to rising production costs
Example: An oil price spike shifts SRAS left, raising prices and lowering output
CLEP Trap: Students misidentify this as an AD shift when the cost side is changing

Definition: Combination of high inflation and high unemployment typically caused by a negative supply shock
Example: 1970s oil shocks led to rising prices and rising unemployment
CLEP Trap: Students assume inflation and unemployment always move opposite because of Phillips curve

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Total demand for goods and services at various price levels; sum of C, I, G, and net exports
Example: Increase in government spending shifts AD right, raising real GDP and price level in short run
CLEP Trap: Students treat AD like individual market demand rather than economy-wide demand

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: AD slopes downward due to wealth effect, interest rate effect, and net export effect
Example: Higher price level reduces real wealth, discourages spending, and raises interest rates
CLEP Trap: Students wrongly use substitution effect to explain AD slope (micro concept)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Changes in consumption, investment, government spending, or net exports that shift AD
Example: Increase in consumer confidence raises C, shifting AD right
CLEP Trap: Students confuse movement along AD from price change with shifts due to non-price factors

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Relationship between price level and real output supplied when some input prices are sticky
Example: Firms increase output when price level rises because nominal wages lag behind
CLEP Trap: Students think SRAS is vertical like LRAS; in short run it slopes upward

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Changes in input prices, productivity, business taxes/subsidies, and supply shocks shift SRAS
Example: A wage increase shifts SRAS left as production becomes more costly
CLEP Trap: Misidentifying AD shifts (spending changes) as SRAS shifts (cost changes)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Vertical line at potential output showing economy's full-employment real GDP when prices and wages are fully flexible
Example: More capital and better technology shift LRAS right, increasing potential GDP
CLEP Trap: Students think changes in price level shift LRAS; only real resource and technology changes do

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Short-run equilibrium at intersection of AD and SRAS, determining actual output and price level
Example: AD and SRAS intersect at real GDP below LRAS, indicating recessionary gap
CLEP Trap: Students confuse short-run equilibrium (AD–SRAS) with long-run equilibrium (AD–SRAS–LRAS intersection)

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: When actual real GDP is less than potential output; unemployment above natural rate
Example: AD and SRAS intersect left of LRAS, GDP below full-employment level
CLEP Trap: Students misclassify a high price level as an inflationary gap even if output is below potential

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: When actual real GDP is greater than potential output; unemployment below natural rate
Example: AD and SRAS intersect right of LRAS, GDP above sustainable long-run level
CLEP Trap: Looking only at inflation and ignoring that output is above potential can confuse gap type

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Fraction of additional income that households spend on consumption
Example: If income rises by $100 and consumption rises by $80, MPC = 0.8
CLEP Trap: Students choose MPC and MPS values that don't sum to 1, leading to wrong multipliers

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Fraction of additional income that households save
Example: If income rises by $100 and saving rises by $20, MPS = 0.2
CLEP Trap: Forgetting that MPC + MPS must equal 1 causes inconsistent calculations

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Factor by which an initial change in spending results in larger change in equilibrium GDP
Example: With MPC = 0.75, multiplier = 4; $10b more G → up to $40b more GDP
CLEP Trap: Students invert formula or use total consumption instead of MPC

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Change in equilibrium GDP resulting from a change in taxes, smaller in magnitude than spending multiplier
Example: With MPC = 0.75, tax multiplier = −3; $10b tax cut → up to $30b more GDP
CLEP Trap: Students forget sign; tax multiplier is negative because taxes move opposite of GDP

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Reduction in private investment caused by higher interest rates from increased government borrowing
Example: Government deficit financing pushes up interest rates, discouraging business investment
CLEP Trap: Students assume government spending always fully boosts GDP; crowding out can limit effect

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Budget components that automatically adjust with economic conditions, helping smooth the business cycle
Example: Progressive income taxes and unemployment insurance increase deficits in recessions without new laws
CLEP Trap: Students label one-time stimulus bills as automatic; those are discretionary policies

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 3 National Income and Price Determination
Definition: Deliberate changes in government spending or taxation passed by policymakers to affect AD
Example: Congress passes a new infrastructure bill to fight recession
CLEP Trap: Students confuse automatic changes in tax revenue with discretionary action requiring legislation

Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Definition: Three roles of money: medium of exchange, unit of account, and store of value
Example: Using dollars to buy groceries (medium), compare values (unit), and save purchasing power (store)
CLEP Trap: Students add 'measure of wealth' as a function; it is not one of the three core functions

Definition: Most liquid forms of money: currency in circulation plus checkable (demand) deposits and traveler's checks
Example: Cash in your wallet and balance in checking account
CLEP Trap: Students include savings accounts and large time deposits, which are in M2, not M1

Definition: Broader measure including M1 plus savings deposits, small time deposits, and some money market funds
Example: Savings account plus checking account plus small certificates of deposit
CLEP Trap: Confusing M1 and M2 on exam questions about liquidity

Definition: System in which banks keep only a fraction of deposits as reserves and lend out the rest
Example: Bank holds 10 percent of deposits in reserve and loans out 90 percent
CLEP Trap: Students assume banks must hold 100 percent of deposits, missing the money creation mechanism

Definition: Fraction of deposits banks are required by regulation to hold as reserves
Example: If rr is 0.1, bank must hold $10 of every $100 deposit as reserves
CLEP Trap: Students forget to convert percentage to decimal when using in formulas

Definition: Maximum potential increase in money supply from a new deposit given the reserve ratio
Example: If rr = 0.1, multiplier = 10; $100 new reserves could support $1000 additional deposits
CLEP Trap: Using excess reserves instead of total rr or inverting rr incorrectly

Definition: Market in which the supply and demand for money determine the nominal interest rate
Example: Increase in money supply shifts vertical MS right and lowers nominal interest rates
CLEP Trap: Students confuse this with loanable funds market, which uses real interest rate and different curves

Definition: Market where savers supply and borrowers demand funds, determining real interest rate
Example: Government deficit increases demand for loanable funds, raising real interest rate
CLEP Trap: Students use nominal instead of real rate when interpreting this graph

Definition: Central bank's buying or selling of government bonds to change the money supply
Example: Fed buys bonds from banks, increasing reserves and money supply
CLEP Trap: Students often reverse effects: buying bonds is expansionary, selling is contractionary
Related Formula/Relationship: Buy bonds → MS↑; Sell bonds → MS↓

Definition: Interest rate the central bank charges commercial banks for loans
Example: Fed lowers discount rate to encourage banks to borrow reserves
CLEP Trap: Overemphasis on discount rate; in practice open market operations are primary tool

Definition: Nominal interest rate adjusted for inflation, reflecting true cost of borrowing in purchasing power terms
Example: If nominal rate is 7 percent and inflation is 3 percent, real rate ≈ 4 percent
CLEP Trap: Students forget to subtract inflation or mistakenly add it

Definition: Theory stating that, with stable velocity and real output, changes in money supply lead to proportional changes in price level
Example: If M doubles while V and Q stay constant, P roughly doubles
CLEP Trap: Students think increasing money supply raises real GDP indefinitely; long run mainly affects prices

Definition: Definition
Example: Definition
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Definition: Use of government spending and taxation to influence aggregate demand and stabilize the economy
Example: Increasing infrastructure spending or cutting income taxes to fight recession
CLEP Trap: Students mix fiscal tools (G and T) with monetary tools (money supply, interest rates)

Definition: Increase in government spending and/or decrease in taxes to increase AD and close a recessionary gap
Example: Government passes a stimulus package that boosts G and cuts T
CLEP Trap: Assuming full multiplier impact without considering crowding out or import leakages

Definition: Decrease in government spending and/or increase in taxes to reduce AD and fight inflation
Example: Government raises taxes and cuts military spending in an overheated economy
CLEP Trap: Students reverse direction of G and T in describing contractionary policies

Definition: Central bank actions that change the money supply and interest rates to influence AD
Example: Fed buys bonds to increase money supply and lower interest rates
CLEP Trap: Students attribute changes in taxes or government spending to the central bank instead of legislature

Definition: Policies that increase money supply and lower interest rates to stimulate investment and AD
Example: Fed buys bonds, reducing interest rates and encouraging borrowing
CLEP Trap: Students think lower interest rates always strengthen currency; actually lower real rates can cause depreciation

Definition: Policies that decrease money supply and raise interest rates to reduce AD and inflation
Example: Fed sells bonds, raising interest rates and discouraging borrowing
CLEP Trap: Students sometimes call bond sales 'stimulus' because government is 'spending', but it's contractionary

Definition: Downward-sloping relationship between inflation and unemployment in the short run
Example: Lower unemployment tends to coincide with higher inflation and vice versa, given current expectations
CLEP Trap: Students apply this trade-off to long run where it no longer holds

Definition: Vertical line at the natural rate of unemployment, indicating no long-term trade-off between inflation and unemployment
Example: At any inflation rate, unemployment returns to its natural rate in the long run
CLEP Trap: Students draw LRPC as downward sloping, suggesting permanent trade-off

Definition: People's inflation expectations shift the short-run Phillips curve; higher expected inflation shifts SRPC up
Example: If workers expect higher inflation, they demand higher nominal wages, raising costs and shifting SRPC up
CLEP Trap: Ignoring expectations, students think policy can permanently lower unemployment with higher inflation
Related Formula/Relationship: Higher expected inflation → SRPC shifts up

Definition: Occurs when government spending exceeds tax revenues in a given year
Example: If G is $500b and T is $400b, deficit is $100b
CLEP Trap: Students confuse annual deficit (flow) with national debt (stock of accumulated past deficits)
Related Formula/Relationship: Deficit = G − T when G > T

Definition: Total accumulated deficits minus surpluses over time
Example: Sum of all past deficits that have not yet been repaid
CLEP Trap: Students think eliminating one year's deficit erases existing national debt
Related Formula/Relationship: Debt = sum of past deficits − surpluses

Definition: Relationship where higher cyclical unemployment is associated with larger negative output gaps
Example: 2 percentage points above natural unemployment roughly corresponds to about 4 percent output gap (approximate)
CLEP Trap: Students expect precise coefficients; CLEP mainly tests qualitative direction
Related Formula/Relationship: Higher unemployment → actual GDP below potential

Definition: Random redistribution of income and wealth between borrowers and lenders, plus increased uncertainty and administrative costs
Example: Higher than expected inflation helps borrowers repay loans with cheaper dollars
CLEP Trap: Students confuse expected inflation (already bargained for) with unexpected, which causes surprises

Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Definition: Increase in real GDP or real GDP per capita over time, especially growth in potential output
Example: Real GDP rising faster than population over decades
CLEP Trap: Students confuse one-time increase in AD with long-run growth in productive capacity
Related Formula/Relationship: Shown by outward shift of LRAS or PPC

Definition: Output per unit of input, often measured as output per worker or output per hour worked
Example: A factory produces more units per worker after adopting new technology
CLEP Trap: Students think productivity is simply 'working harder' rather than better use of capital and technology

Definition: Skills, knowledge, and health embodied in workers that increase productivity
Example: Training programs and education that make workers more efficient
CLEP Trap: Students confuse human capital with physical capital or 'number of workers'

Definition: Man-made resources like machinery, tools, and buildings used in production
Example: Robots on an assembly line and computers in an office
CLEP Trap: Students categorize money as physical capital; money is financial asset, not capital in production sense

Definition: Improvements in knowledge and production methods that allow more output with same inputs
Example: Assembly line innovation doubling car output with same workers and machines
CLEP Trap: Students think 'technology' only means computers; in macro it includes any production process improvement

Definition: Policies aimed at increasing long-run growth via human capital, physical capital, technology, and institutions
Example: Tax credits for R&D, subsidies for education, improved rule of law
CLEP Trap: Students confuse short-run demand-side stimulus with long-run growth policy

Definition: Higher national saving provides more funds for investment, increasing capital stock and future output
Example: Household saving rises, leading to more funds available for firms to buy capital equipment
CLEP Trap: Students see saving as 'bad for demand' and ignore its role in supporting investment and growth

Definition: Large persistent deficits can reduce private investment, slowing capital accumulation and long-run growth
Example: Government borrowing pushes up interest rates, making it harder for firms to finance projects
CLEP Trap: Students focus solely on short-run AD boost from deficits and forget long-run capital effects

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: Definition
Example: Example
CLEP Trap: CLEP Trap

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: Accounting statement of a nation's transactions with the rest of the world, divided into current and financial accounts
Example: US imports goods, exports services, and has capital flows reported in BOP
CLEP Trap: Students think each account must be balanced separately; actually, overall BOP must balance
Related Formula/Relationship: Current account + financial account + statistical discrepancy = 0

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: Part of BOP that records trade in goods and services, net income from abroad, and net current transfers
Example: US exports software and imports oil; net exports and remittances show up here
CLEP Trap: Students include foreign asset purchases here; those belong in financial account

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: Part of BOP that records purchase and sale of financial assets and real assets across borders
Example: Foreigners buying US Treasury bonds or US firms buying foreign factories
CLEP Trap: Students confuse with current account, especially for bond and stock flows

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: Price of one currency in terms of another currency
Example: 1 US dollar trading for 0.9 euros
CLEP Trap: Students mix up direct and indirect quotations and misinterpret appreciation vs depreciation

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: Increase in value of a currency relative to others; each unit buys more foreign currency
Example: Dollar appreciates, making European vacations cheaper for Americans
CLEP Trap: Students assume appreciation is always good; it hurts exports and can reduce net exports

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: Decrease in value of a currency; each unit buys less foreign currency
Example: Dollar depreciates, making US goods cheaper for foreigners
CLEP Trap: Students confuse depreciation with domestic deflation; depreciation specifically refers to exchange rate

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: Market in which currencies are traded, with supply and demand determining exchange rates under floating system
Example: Increase in foreign demand for US assets raises demand for dollars, causing appreciation
CLEP Trap: Students reverse which curve is demand or supply for domestic currency

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Term: Effect of interest rate changes on currency
Definition: Higher domestic real interest rates attract foreign capital, increasing demand for domestic currency and causing appreciation
Example: Fed raises real rates; investors move money into US bonds, pushing up dollar value
CLEP Trap: Students think higher interest rates always improve net exports; appreciation tends to reduce them
Related Formula/Relationship: Higher r → capital inflow → currency appreciates → NX falls

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Term: Effect of fiscal expansion in open economy
Definition: Higher G or lower T can raise interest rates, attract foreign capital, appreciate currency, and reduce net exports, partly offsetting AD increase
Example: Government deficit spending raises rates and dollar value, hurting export sector
CLEP Trap: Students ignore exchange rate channel and overstate AD impact of fiscal policy in open economy

Module 1 Basic Economic Concepts: Module 7 Open Economy International Trade and Finance
Definition: In floating system, trade deficits can lead to currency depreciation over time as more domestic currency is supplied on FOREX
Example: Persistent US trade deficit can weaken the dollar, making exports cheaper and imports more expensive
CLEP Trap: Students expect fixed relationships; in reality, capital flows also drive exchange rates
